Pre-Game Insights: USA will want to take down another Full Member nation in what is likely to be their last game at the World Cup

England have rarely been at their best over the last three weeks in the Caribbean but there have been signs that their game is coming together at the right time for a tilt at becoming the first team to successfully defend the T20 World Cup trophy
Aaron Jones' six over midwicket to seal a rousing opening-night win over Canada was the shot that was heard around the World Cup

Liam Livingstone's attempt to get England over the line against South Africa, helping to revive their chase while adding 78 for the fifth wicket alongside Harry Brook, was only the second time he has scored more than 30 in 22 T20 innings this year
Miscellaneous Highlights: This will be the first meeting between England and USA with full international status in any format
England have played 13 completed T20Is in Bridgetown, winning six (including the 2010 T20 World Cup final) and losing seven
Sam Curran needs one more wicket to reach 50 in T20Is
Others: USA have been without Monank since their group-stage win over Pakistan, but head coach Stuart Law suggested he was close to returning from a shoulder injury
England may be unchanged for the third match running, having apparently settled on Jonny Bairstow at No. 3 and Sam Curran as the extra bowling/left-hand batter option
Kensington Oval is one of only two venues at this World Cup to have seen a 200-plus score, but generally, the pitches have been on the tacky side
The forecast for Sunday has improved although there is still a chance of rainfall interrupting proceedings
